# MSD ServoDrive - DeviceHelp

6.8.1.3 Expanded speed control circuit

There is the option of setting up an expanded speed control circuit when using sensorless control. The reason for this is that the estimated speed from the Kalman filter cannot be calculated with steady-state accuracy, as parameter inaccuracies are inherent to the model.
Q: What is the purpose of the expanded speed control circuit in the MSD ServoDrive?
A1: The expanded speed control circuit is used to improve accuracy when using sensorless control, as the estimated speed from the Kalman filter cannot be calculated with steady-state accuracy due to inherent model parameter inaccuracies.
A2: To enhance speed control accuracy in sensorless operations, since the Kalman filter's speed estimation lacks steady-state precision because of model parameter inaccuracies.
A3: It compensates for the steady-state accuracy limitations of the Kalman filter's speed estimation in sensorless control by addressing inherent model parameter inaccuracies.
A4: The circuit is designed to mitigate the effects of model parameter inaccuracies on the Kalman filter's speed estimation in sensorless control scenarios.
A5: For sensorless control applications, this circuit ensures more accurate speed control by overcoming the Kalman filter's limitations in steady-state accuracy caused by model parameter inaccuracies.

Q: Why can't the estimated speed from the Kalman filter be calculated with steady-state accuracy in the MSD ServoDrive?
A1: Because parameter inaccuracies are inherent to the model used by the Kalman filter.
A2: The model's inherent parameter inaccuracies prevent the Kalman filter from achieving steady-state accuracy in speed estimation.
A3: Steady-state accuracy is compromised due to the model's built-in parameter inaccuracies affecting the Kalman filter's calculations.
A4: Inaccuracies within the model's parameters naturally limit the Kalman filter's ability to estimate speed with steady-state accuracy.
A5: The Kalman filter's speed estimation lacks steady-state accuracy because the model it relies on contains inherent parameter inaccuracies.
